questions.text: Match the Dermatological disorders in Column A with their respective investigations in Column B: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Correct matches:
  • • Correct matches:
  • • 1. Tinea : Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis, are fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails. The diagnosis is commonly made by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings, which reveals fungal hyphae under a microscope.
  • • 1. Tinea
  • • 2. Lepromatous leprosy : This form of leprosy is diagnosed using a slit skin smear, where a sample from the skin lesion is stained and examined for the presence of acid-fast bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae).
  • • 2. Lepromatous leprosy
  • • 3. Lupus vulgaris : Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. The diagnosis often involves a biopsy of the lesion, which shows granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis and the presence of acid-fast bacilli.
  • • 3. Lupus vulgaris
  • • 4. Allergic dermatitis : Allergic contact dermatitis is diagnosed using a patch test, where suspected allergens are applied to the skin under occlusive patches to observe for a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • • 4. Allergic dermatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tinea is diagnosed with a KOH mount, lepromatous leprosy with a slit skin smear, lupus vulgaris with a biopsy, and allergic dermatitis with a patch test.

questions.text: Statement 1: Clinically a patient having flaccid bullae with painful erosions, will show Suprabasal split and inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft on histopathological examination. Statement 2: Row of tombstones appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Statement 1 is false and Statement 2 is true

options.label: B
options.text: Statement 1 is true and Statement 2 is false

options.label: C
options.text: Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1

options.label: D
options.text: Both the statements are true and 2 is the conclusion of 1

questions.correct_answer: C. Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris , a blistering autoimmune skin condition. The condition is characterized by suprabasal acantholysis (a separation of skin cells above the basal cell layer), leading to the formation of flaccid bullae with painful erosions. The "row of tombstones" appearance describes a specific histological feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris
  • ➤ suprabasal acantholysis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of red spots on her legs that have persisted for several days. She denies any recent trauma or new medications. On examination, there are multiple red and purple areas on her lower legs that do not blanch with pressure. Laboratory evaluation reveals normal platelet counts and no signs of infection. The patient reports having a history of easy bruising and occasional nosebleeds. Which of the following options represents a primary skin lesion seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Purpura is a primary skin lesion characterized by red or purple spots that do not blanch under pressure, resulting from the extravasation of red blood cells into the skin or mucous membranes. It is commonly associated with conditions like vasculitis, thrombocytopenia, or vitamin C deficiency. Primary skin lesions are the initial manifestations of a disease process on the skin, indicating an underlying vascular or hematological condition rather than being a result of an external factor or the progression of a skin disorder.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Scab : A scab, or crust, is a secondary skin lesion formed by the dried exudate of blood, serum, or pus over an injured or broken skin area. It is not a primary lesion as it develops after skin damage.
  • • Option B. Scab
  • • Option C. Lichenification : Lichenification is a secondary lesion characterized by thickened, leathery skin with pronounced skin lines, resulting from chronic scratching or rubbing. It does not originate directly but rather is a reaction to chronic irritation.
  • • Option C. Lichenification
  • • Option D. Scar : A scar is a secondary lesion resulting from the healing of skin injuries such as lacerations, burns, or surgery. It represents fibrous tissue that replaces normal skin following injury and is not considered a primary lesion.
  • • Option D. Scar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purpura is a primary skin lesion that suggests an underlying vascular or coagulation disorder, setting it apart from secondary skin lesions such as crusts, atrophy, and induration, which arise from external factors or the advancement of skin conditions.

questions.text: Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to which of the following persons? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022) Sharing the same clothes, towels Living with a patient with leprosy for > 6 month Contact of age more than 2 years Contact for more than 20 hours per week.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy is crucial for contacts who have had significant exposure to an individual with leprosy, particularly those living in the same household or in close contact for extended periods.
  • ➤ Rifampicin:
  • ➤ Rifampicin:
  • ➤ A single dose of 600 mg kills more than 99% of the susceptible organisms present at the start of treatment, that is as much as 3 to 6 months of daily treatment with the combination dapsone plus Clofazimine. Rifampicin has become established as a highly potent bactericidal drug , and it acts by inhibiting the bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase . Single Dose of Rifampicin (SDR) is used in chemoprophylaxis. Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient so as to ensure the patient is non-infectious .
  • ➤ A single dose of 600 mg kills more than 99% of the susceptible organisms present at the start of treatment, that is as much as 3 to 6 months of daily treatment with the combination dapsone plus Clofazimine.

questions.text: A 38-year-old married woman presents with painful blisters on her oral mucosa and genital areas, with a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits, as depicted below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by painful blisters on the skin and mucous membranes, such as the oral and genital areas. The histopathological finding of a suprabasal split and the presence of intercellular IgG deposits in a fishnet pattern on immunofluorescence are hallmark features of pemphigus vulgaris. These findings distinguish it from other blistering diseases.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Dermatitis herpetiformis: Typically presents with intensely pruritic vesicles on extensor surfaces, and histopathology would show subepidermal blisters with neutrophils in the dermal papillae, not a suprabasal split.
  • • Option A. Dermatitis herpetiformis:
  • • Option C. Behçet's disease: Usually presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers but does not show the characteristic suprabasal split or IgG deposits seen in pemphigus vulgaris.
  • • Option C. Behçet's disease:
  • • Option D. Allergic dermatitis: This condition generally presents with eczematous lesions and would not show the suprabasal split or intercellular IgG deposits characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.
  • • Option D. Allergic dermatitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by painful blisters on mucous membranes, a suprabasal split on histology, and intercellular IgG deposits with a fishnet pattern on immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesions as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pustular psoriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient with a history of psoriasis presents with fever, malaise , and widespread pustules following the abrupt withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, consider pustular psoriasis as the probable diagnosis. This condition can be a severe, life-threatening variant of psoriasis that requires prompt medical attention and management.
  • ➤ When a patient with a history of psoriasis presents with fever, malaise , and widespread pustules following the abrupt withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, consider pustular psoriasis as the probable diagnosis.

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with the following lesion on the lateral aspect of the tongue as shown in the image below. This white membrane was not scrapeable with a gauze piece. What is the diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral Hairy Leucoplakia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Lichen Planus :
  • • Option B. Lichen Planus
  • • This condition usually presents as white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae) as shown in the image below, on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa .
  • • This condition usually presents as white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae) as shown in the image below, on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa .
  • • white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae)
  • • buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa
  • • It can sometimes have erosive, painful areas , but it does not have the "hairy" appearance typical of Oral Hairy Leukoplakia.
  • • It can sometimes have erosive, painful areas , but it does not have the "hairy" appearance typical of Oral Hairy Leukoplakia.
  • • erosive, painful areas
  • • Option C. Lichen Sclerosus :
  • • Option C. Lichen Sclerosus
  • • This is a chronic condition that typically affects the anogenital area , not the oral mucosa.
  • • This is a chronic condition that typically affects the anogenital area , not the oral mucosa.
  • • anogenital area
  • • It is characterized by white patches that can lead to scarring , but it does not occur on the tongue.
  • • It is characterized by white patches that can lead to scarring , but it does not occur on the tongue.
  • • white patches
  • • scarring
  • • Option D. Candidiasis :
  • • Option D. Candidiasis
  • • Also known as oral thrush , candidiasis presents with white patches that typically can be scraped off to reveal a red, bleeding surface underneath. The fact that the lesion in the image is not scrapeable makes candidiasis less likely.
  • • Also known as oral thrush , candidiasis presents with white patches that typically can be scraped off to reveal a red, bleeding surface underneath. The fact that the lesion in the image is not scrapeable makes candidiasis less likely.
  • • oral thrush
  • • scraped off
  • • red, bleeding surface

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in i mmunocompromised patients.
  • ➤ Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in i mmunocompromised patients.
  • ➤ Oral Hairy Leukoplakia
  • ➤ non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral
  • ➤ mmunocompromised
  • ➤ Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9 th edition Page no 25.33

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the clinic with concerns about genital warts that have recurred several times over the past year. She has been in a monogamous relationship with her husband for the last three years. Her husband, however, has never shown any symptoms of warts or other visible lesions. The patient has tried several treatments, including cryotherapy and topical medications, but the warts keep coming back. She is particularly worried about the risk of transmitting the infection to her husband, who is currently asymptomatic. The patient asks what steps she can take to prevent passing the infection to her partner. Which of the following is the most appropriate advice to prevent transmission of genital warts to her husband?

options.label: A
options.text: Use condoms consistently during all sexual activity

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid sexual contact when active lesions are present

options.label: C
options.text: Apply antiviral prophylaxis before sexual activity

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccinate her husband with the HPV vaccine

questions.correct_answer: B. Avoid sexual contact when active lesions are present
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Avoiding sexual contact when active lesions are present is the most effective way to prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Genital warts, primarily caused by HPV types 6 and 11, are highly infectious, especially during periods when lesions are visible and active. Abstaining from sexual activity when lesions are present significantly reduces the risk of transmitting the virus to a partner. Unlike other sexually transmitted infections, there is no effective antiviral prophylaxis available for HPV, making abstinence during active outbreaks a critical preventive measure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Use condoms consistently during all sexual activity While condoms can reduce the risk of HPV transmission, they do not provide complete protection, especially since HPV can infect areas not covered by a condom. This measure is beneficial but less effective than abstaining from sexual contact during active outbreaks.
  • • Option A. Use condoms consistently during all sexual activity
  • • Option C. Apply antiviral prophylaxis before sexual activity There are currently no effective antiviral medications available for the prophylaxis of HPV infection. Topical treatments, such as imiquimod and podophyllotoxin, are used to treat active lesions but do not prevent the transmission of HPV.
  • • Option C. Apply antiviral prophylaxis before sexual activity
  • • Option D. Vaccinate her husband with the HPV vaccine The HPV vaccine is effective in preventing HPV-related conditions, including genital warts, in individuals who have not been previously exposed to the virus types covered by the vaccine. However, it does not provide immediate protection and is not effective as a post-exposure treatment or in preventing transmission of existing infections.
  • • Option D. Vaccinate her husband with the HPV vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genital warts, caused by HPV, are highly contagious, especially when lesions are active. The best preventive measure is to avoid sexual contact during periods of visible lesions, as there is no antiviral prophylaxis available. Condoms reduce but do not eliminate transmission risk, and vaccines are preventative but not curative once infection has occurred.

questions.text: (1-3)-B-D glucan assay cannot be used in? (INICET NOV 2017)

questions.text: A farmer was sleeping in the field, and he felt a sting on his leg. He saw something moving away quickly. He then got drowsy and was taken to the hospital. He developed pain around the site and continued to bleed profusely from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following is the most likely cause? ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Viper

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viper bites are characterized by profuse bleeding, pain, redness, and blister formation due to their vasculotoxic venom.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a placebo? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Herbal medication with no effect known

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Sham surgery

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Potassium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.
  • • Chemoreceptors are made up of two types of cells, type I or glomus cells and type II or sustentacular cells. Glomus cells have afferent nerve endings, which are stimulated by hypoxia. Type II cells are glial cells and provide support for type I cells.
  • • Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels. Conductance of these channels is reduced proportionally to the degree of hypoxia resulting in K+ efflux → depolarization of cell and causes Ca+ influx →Excitation of afferent nerve ending.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Calcium : Calcium is also involved but primarily in response to the depolarization initiated by changes in potassium ion conductance. It is not the initial ion involved in oxygen sensing.
  • • Option B. Calcium
  • • Option C. Sodium : Sodium ions are not directly involved in the oxygen-sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.
  • • Option C. Sodium
  • • Option D. Chlorine : Chlorine ions are not involved in the oxygen-sensing functions of peripheral chemoreceptors.
  • • Option D. Chlorine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Potassium ions are crucial for the function of peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors, where they regulate the membrane potential and responsiveness of the cells to hypoxia. This process is vital for the body's ability to detect and respond to low oxygen levels, ensuring adequate oxygenation and cellular function.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl went out playing. After coming home, she looked confused. Parents brought her to the hospital, and on examination, she looked irritable and has not passed urine since morning. Her friends said she had something while playing. Which of the following is the likely intoxication and the correct antidote? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Datura; Physostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic toxicity, characterized by confusion, urinary retention, and other anticholinergic symptoms. The antidote for such toxicity is physostigmine, a cholinergic agent that increases acetylcholine levels by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase.

questions.text: You are in the operating room and notice the tracing in gray color waveform on this device. What does it indicate? ( INICET May 2021)

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals Were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110 min. What is the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Transfusion related circulatory overload

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) is a potential complication of blood transfusion, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions like CKD. It presents with respiratory distress, hypertension, and tachycardia and can be prevented by careful monitoring and slow transfusion.

questions.text: Which require maximum energy for assimilation? ( INICET Nov 2021)

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In heart failure patients with elevated potassium levels, loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred to manage fluid overload and avoid exacerbation of hyperkalemia, unlike potassium-sparing diuretics or ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A sexually active male presents with warts on his penis. Which strains of HPV are most commonly responsible for these lesions? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Genital warts, including those on the penis, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) strains 6 and 11. These strains are known for their low oncogenic potential, meaning they are less likely to lead to cancer but are responsible for the majority of anogenital wart cases. The warts typically appear as small, papillary lesions that can be either smooth or rough and often occur in groups.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. HPV 1, 2, and 3: These strains are associated with common warts (verruca vulgaris) and plantar warts, not genital warts.
  • • Option A. HPV 1, 2, and 3:
  • • Option B. HPV 3, 5: These strains are linked to epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare skin disorder, and not to genital warts.
  • • Option B. HPV 3, 5:
  • • Option D. HPV 16 and 18: While these strains have high oncogenic potential and are associated with cervical cancer and other malignancies, they are less commonly the cause of genital warts compared to HPV 6 and 11.
  • • Option D. HPV 16 and 18:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV strains 6 and 11 are the most common causes of genital warts, including those found on the penis, and are characterized by their low oncogenic potential.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? ( INICET May 2024)

questions.text: Which of the options below is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast

questions.correct_answer: A. Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tumor size <4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast conservative surgery involves the removal of the primary breast cancer with adequate normal breast tissue, followed by adjuvant radiotherapy and assessment of regional lymph nodes through a separate axillary incision.
  • ➤ Absolute contraindications for breast conservative surgery include pregnancy, persistently positive margins, multicentric lumps, diffuse microcalcification, extensive ductal carcinoma in situ, and inflammatory breast cancer.
  • ➤ Relative contraindications include active systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, a large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump), known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), multifocal disease, and prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast.

  • ➤ Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)

  • ➤ Hyperkalemia
  • ➤ They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a: ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).
  • • Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.
  • • Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.
  • • Option A. Plane synovial:
  • • Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.
  • • Option B.
  • • Primary cartilaginous:
  • • Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.
  • • Option C. Secondary cartilaginous:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:
  • ➤ Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:
  • ➤ Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint Middle radioulnar joint Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Middle radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint
  • ➤ Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.
  • ➤ The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:
  • ➤ The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.
  • ➤ The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  • ➤ Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a laceration on her forearm after falling on rough concrete. The physician explains that the injury affects a structure primarily composed of dense irregular collagen, contributing to the skin's ability to resist tearing. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this injury?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The reticular dermis, a deeper layer of the skin, is primarily composed of dense irregular connective tissue. This type of tissue contains collagen fibers arranged in various directions, providing the skin with the ability to withstand mechanical stress from multiple angles. The reticular dermis is crucial in maintaining the structural integrity and flexibility of the skin, allowing it to resist tearing during physical trauma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tendon Tendons are composed of dense regular connective tissue, where collagen fibers are aligned parallel to one another, allowing for high tensile strength in a single direction. Tendons primarily connect muscles to bones, facilitating movement, and do not provide multi-directional strength like dense irregular connective tissue.
  • • Option B. Tendon
  • • Option C. Hyaline cartilage Hyaline cartilage is made up of a gel-like matrix with chondrocytes and collagen fibers, providing smooth surfaces for joint movement and support in respiratory structures. It does not contain dense irregular connective tissue and is not involved in resisting mechanical stress in the skin.
  • • Option C. Hyaline cartilage
  • • Option D. Elastic artery Elastic arteries, such as the aorta, are composed of a mix of elastic and smooth muscle fibers, allowing them to stretch and recoil with the pulsatile flow of blood. Their structure is not related to dense irregular connective tissue, and they serve different functions compared to the dermis.
  • • Option D. Elastic artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The reticular dermis, part of the skin's deeper layer, is composed of dense irregular connective tissue rich in collagen fibers oriented in multiple directions. This arrangement provides the skin with structural integrity and elasticity, enabling it to withstand mechanical stress from various angles, which is crucial for protecting underlying tissues from injury.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been diagnosed with achalasia cardia through esophageal manometry. The manometry results reveal simultaneous, high-pressure contractions in the distal esophagus, along with spasmodic contractions. What type of achalasia does this patient's presentation correspond among the provided options?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type III achalasia, also known as spastic achalasia, involves spastic contractions in the distal esophagus and failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax. This type is the least common and often requires more aggressive therapy.

questions.text: Fatty acid transport through mitochondrial membrane is via? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Carnitine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fatty acid transport through the mitochondrial membrane involves the carnitine shuttle system. Long-chain fatty acids are activated to form fatty acyl-CoA in the cytoplasm. Carnitine acyltransferase I (CAT I) then catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming fatty acyl-carnitine.
  • ➤ Fatty acyl-carnitine is transported across the mitochondrial membrane via a carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase.Once inside the mitochondrial matrix, carnitine acyltransferase II (CAT II) catalyzes the transfer of the acyl group back to CoA, allowing the fatty acid to undergo β-oxidation.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 208

questions.text: A pregnant woman has gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and her blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin. What will be the appropriate gestational age for her delivery? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 39 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The appropriate timing of delivery in a pregnant woman with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) whose blood glucose levels are well controlled on insulin is at or after 39 weeks of gestation. This recommendation is based on the following considerations:
  • • Lung Maturity: GDM pregnancies are associated with a delay in fetal lung maturity. Routine delivery before 39 weeks is generally not recommended to avoid respiratory complications in the newborn. Induction of Labor: If the patient with well-controlled GDM has not delivered spontaneously by 39 weeks, induction of labor should be scheduled at or after 39 weeks to minimize the risks associated with GDM and to ensure fetal maturity.
  • • Lung Maturity: GDM pregnancies are associated with a delay in fetal lung maturity. Routine delivery before 39 weeks is generally not recommended to avoid respiratory complications in the newborn.
  • • Lung Maturity:
  • • Induction of Labor: If the patient with well-controlled GDM has not delivered spontaneously by 39 weeks, induction of labor should be scheduled at or after 39 weeks to minimize the risks associated with GDM and to ensure fetal maturity.
  • • Induction of Labor:
  • • Other important points in GDM:
  • • Other important points in GDM:
  • • Avoid Past Dates: Delivery should not be delayed beyond the expected due date to prevent complications. Anticipate Shoulder Dystocia: There is an increased risk of shoulder dystocia in infants of mothers with GDM. Prophylactic Cesarean Section (LSCS): Considered if the estimated fetal weight is greater than 4.5 kg to avoid complications during vaginal delivery.
  • • Avoid Past Dates: Delivery should not be delayed beyond the expected due date to prevent complications.
  • • Avoid Past Dates:
  • • Anticipate Shoulder Dystocia: There is an increased risk of shoulder dystocia in infants of mothers with GDM.
  • • Anticipate Shoulder Dystocia:
  • • Prophylactic Cesarean Section (LSCS): Considered if the estimated fetal weight is greater than 4.5 kg to avoid complications during vaginal delivery.
  • • Prophylactic Cesarean Section (LSCS):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pregnant woman with well-controlled gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) on insulin, the appropriate gestational age for delivery is at or after 39 weeks to ensure fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of complications.
  • ➤ Ref: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/National_Guidelines_for_Diagnosis_&_Management_of_Gestational_Diabetes_Mellitus.pdf
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/National_Guidelines_for_Diagnosis_&_Management_of_Gestational_Diabetes_Mellitus.pdf

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. High

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When assessing the risk of pulmonary embolism, especially in postoperative patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of DVT, it is essential to consider both the clinical presentation and the surgical history. The Wells score is a valuable tool in stratifying the risk and guiding further diagnostic testing and management. In this scenario, the patient falls into a high-risk category, indicating that further immediate investigation, typically with imaging like a CT pulmonary angiogram, is warranted.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - UpToDate/Wells score

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the options below is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High LDL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, criterion for metabolic syndromes are:

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli O157: H7? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sorbitol MacConkey agar is critical for distinguishing E. coli O157 from other E. coli strains due to its unique inability to ferment sorbitol, helping guide appropriate public health responses and treatment options during outbreaks of foodborne illness.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. Her vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. Which of the following is used as first-line management to treat the condition? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia, adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs
